value: Elevation of Two Columns, Possibly from Campanile of San Zeno, Verona, Italy

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating two columns, possibly the same one but seen from a different side so as to indicate the carving composition on the opposite side of the capital.  The column at left has a cuboidal capital supporting a large cushion-like cap.  The capital at right is similar in its shape but has a faintly carved profile of a leaf at either corner and a small rosette in the upper center.  The dimensions of the columns at various heights has been inscribed.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on very smooth, off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

value: Sheet: 31.4 x 21 cm (12 3/8 x 8 1/4 in.), irregular
Structure with Pointed Arch from Chapel at Amboise, France

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating a small table pierced by tri-cusped Gothic arch in center, and with small diamond-shaped notches carved out of the spandrel corners surrounding the arch.  Above this is a three part moulding that makes up the table top.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on off-white wove paper with pre-printed blue ink ruled lines, mounted to thick, off-white laid paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Dimensions

Sketch of Column in Gothic Style, Chapel at Amboise, France

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating a column in the Gothic style consisting of a very tall base with an elongated midsection with carved tri-cusped arch.  To the right is a detail of the base of the midsection, showing that it is hollowed out so that the interior is concave and framed by slender engaged colonettes on either side.

Plan of Main Wall Inside, Chapel at Amboise, France

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating a space with a cruciform plan.  Various supporting elements of the wall have been shaded, and dimensions of certain elements have been inscribed.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on off-white wove paper with pre-printed blue ink ruled lines, mounted to thick, off-white laid paper tipped into binding with fabric

Elevation of the Side of an Ornate Cabinet

label: Description
value: One side of an ornate cabinet shown in elevation with a winged, armless satyress prominately featured in profile. One half of cabinet design is shown with a large rectangular section supported by the design of lower verticle doors. Above, is an entablature with a vase of fowers between cornice and pedestles on top.

label: Physical description
value: Black chalk; pen and brown ink on cream laid paper, laid down
Sketch of Iron Gate, Possibly Italy?

label: Description
value: Narrow sheet that has been cut down from a larger sheet and tipped vertically into binding depicting a section of an iron gate with interlocking scroll ornament and stylized ornament like a fleur-de-lis.  Above is a very light sketch of a colonnaded classical building with triangular pediment, and there is another sketch of intersecting horizontal and vertical members below this, possibly related to the larger sketch of ironwork.  The sheet is made of multiple thickness of paper that seem to have been laminated together. The bottom right corner of the sheet is separating. There are various inscriptions with measurements.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite with trace of brush with blue and gray wash on very smooth, thick, off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Dimensions
value: Sheet: 31.8 x 12.4 cm (12 1/2 x 4 7/8 in.), irregular
Octagonal Plan and Elevation of a Monument

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet folded to create two vertical halves. At left is an octagonal plan of a space, with smaller detailed sketches of the molding profile of a base, and to the right a detail of the entablature of an unknown structure, its molding types delineated clearly.  The right sheet contains a quickly drawn selevation of a monument with scrolling pediment and urn finial supported by two uniformly plain columns, all set upon a faceted base.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on very smooth, thin cream wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Dimensions
value: Sheet: 29.5 x 46 cm (11 5/8 x 18 1/8 in.), approximate

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet folded vertically to create two faces of drawing space.  The sheet has been tipped into the binding so that the interior surfaces are read upside down.  The left sheet (when read correctly) contains the profile of a molded base consisting of multiple types: laurel, leaf and dart, and lozenge.  Below this is a square panel with inset carving inscribed in a circle.  The sheet at right consists of a profile of the base of a pilaster above, and detail of an architrave below.  The architrave has an elaborate griffon and scrollwork frieze.  The verso of the right sheet (read upside down) contains the plan of an octagonal well with steps radiating outward. The upper part of this sheet has been cut off but a sketch of a band of carving remains. The verso of the left sheet (also read upside down) contains an elevation of a rectangular reservoir with a plaque that reads G R A and terminates in a large carved shell above.  The plaque just mentioned is rendered larger to the right of this drawing.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on very smooth, thin cream wove paper, folded and tipped into binding with fabric

label: Dimensions
value: Sheet: 31.4 x 49 cm (12 3/8 x 19 5/16 in.), approximate
Sketches of Details and Plan of Architectural Elements, Tower at Milan, Italy

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet tipped horizontally into binding consisting mainly of inscriptions and a few small sketches.  At center left is a plan view of an arcade supported by three columns.  To the right of this is a small column supporting an architrave and rendered separately below it is the base of the same column, its dimensions included as well.  At bottom left is another molding profile.  The verso contains a similarly high ratio of inscriptions to sketches.  At the very top of the sheet is a small, square plan, and to the right of it a view in plan of a span supported by a composition of double colonettes and a single colonette. The rest of the sheet below this contains inscriptions.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on smooth, thick off-white wove paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Dimensions
value: Sheet: 25.1 x 16.3 cm (9 7/8 x 6 7/16 in.), irregular

label: Description
value: Narrow vertical sheet tipped horizontally into binding illustrating in upper half of sheet the elevation of a pointed arched loggia supported by nondescript columns.  Below this is a larger detail of four arches and the capitals of their column supports.  The verso contains an elevation with dimensions of a double arched window opening.  There are inscriptions with measurements on both the recto and verso; refer to image.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on smooth, thick off-white wove paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet cut down and with left edge folded on top of drawing.  Recto depicts a sailboat tethered to the left of a dock, with elements of rigging and scaffolding seen on the dock. Verso is a view of small waves lapping a shoreline with descriptions about the color of waves and sand inscribed in the drawing.

label: Physical description
value: Recto: brush and watercolor, graphite on cream wove paper; verso: graphite

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet depicting a large boat with two striped masts near or beached on the shoreline.  It is possibly a clipper ship with its third mast broken.  Its stern faces the viewer and on the rocky beach smaller boats are beached and figures seem to load or unload cargo to the larger boart.  In the distance at right is the triangular gray sail of another boat, and an open body of water beyond.

label: Physical description

Front Elevation, Proposed Library Museum for J. Pierpont Morgan, Esq., New York

label: Description
value: View of pavilion facade.  Exterior with semi-circular columed, stepped portico and recessed niches filled with sculpture on either side of central doorway.  Above doorway, eyebrow window with balustrade, decorated low dome with balustrade motif on top. Suggestions of porches left and right of pavilion with trees behind.

Elevation of Proposed House for George Eustis, Esq.

label: Description
value: From 1896 to 1898 Whitney Warren worked intermittently in the offices of McKim, Mead & White as a draftsman, this drawing of a proposed house for George Eustis, however, was to be his own commission. The house is to be three stories, below a roof with a prominent cornice, and with a classically inspired facade.

label: Physical description

Plans, elevation, and section of the tower in Chiaravalle, Milanese, Italy

label: Description
value: Like all Beaux-Arts trained architects of his generation, Warren learned his art by sketching and painting, especially during his travels through Holland, northern France, Germany, and Italy. Though familiar with the key monuments of Europe, Warren seemed more interested in ordinary structures, and began building a visual library of details that would make up his visual vocabulary. To him, a foundation in drawing was essential for an architect. His drawings, such as this one of a bell tower, or campanile, in Chiaravalle, near Milan, Italy, expressed the experimental and romantic quality that would later appear in his works.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite, brush and red and brown watercolor, on cream heavy wove paper
Part of Old Castle, Gernsbach, Germany

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with sketch of a cluster of half-timbered buildings, possibly for storing hay or grains.  The single-story building in the foreground has deep eaves and a single dormer with casement window opening.  A larger but similar building in the mid-ground has a buttressed eave, three window openings and a small chimney.  At the rear of these two buildings is a multistory masonry tower with steep, tiled roof with small windows visible below the roofline.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Rear of Old City Hall, Gernsbach, Germany

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with view looking into a narrow street framed on either side by walls of buildings.  At right there is only a view under the eaves of the building.  The buildings at left are rendered in greater detail, with particular attention paid to the intricate roofline fo the city hall building.  The roofs are all steeply pitched, broken occasionally by chimneys and finials.  The city hall's façade projects wider than the building and its roofline ends in a "crow-step" or "trapgevel" gables with scrolls, typical of German and Dutch Reniassance architecture.  The stpes have three ball and spike finials visible, while the central step has a finial that terminates in a crescent moon.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating a building with a tall, slender tower and small clock in a projecting gable of the structure's main façade.  There is a deep eave projecting over a double-glazed casement window with shutters opened wide.  Above this window and below the clock face is another, smaller window opening at the attic level.  Behind this rises the tower with louvered openings visible on two sides, and is surmounted by a faceted cupola with a ball and spike finial.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Four Sketches: Gables, Dormer, and Holy Water Bucket, Gernsbach, Germany

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with four sketches, clockwise from upper right: dormer; (A) a holy water bucket from a church; a half-timbered façade; (B) a gable with water-shed.  The dormer has a double arched-top window opening and the roof above the dormer is flat.  The holy water bucket is hung by a twisted bale handle on a projecting bracket of copper or wrought iron made of c-scrolls in a Baroque style.  The buliding façade at bottom left is the least refined, and is sketched close to the building as the area under the roof tiles and eaves is visible.  The gable with water-shed is more delicately sketched, showing two bulding rooflines, the one in the background having a projecting eave, visible timber construction, and small window openings punctuating its façades.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
A Warehouse of the 16th Century in Pisa, Italy

label: Description
value: Above, elevation of a slightly, obliquely disposed one-story building of eight bays, five of which contain doors; center, elevation of two of the brick bays; a pedestal with the coat of arms of the Medici rises over a pilaster at left; scale below; lower section, a plan of wall beside a door and a part of the plan of the building.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite, brush and watercolor on paper

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with three sketches of details from buildings in Strasburg, clockwise from top left:view of a roofline corner with a slender chimneytop behind.  The chimneytop has blind panels interrupted by a projecting cornice, above which are two round-arched openings on the two visible façades.  Above this is another projecting cornice surmounted by two gables on either face; at right is a detail of a waterspout visible on a building façade.  The gutter projects from the building and a second piece in the shape of a dragon's head creates the mouth from which the water sprays.  This piece is tethered to the wall of the building by an intricate s-link chain and ornamental bracket.  Below is a three-story building with a prominent, tiled gable roof and multiple chimneys punctuating its roofline.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: View of two or three-story buildings nestled in the foreground of a tall Romanesque style masonry tower.  The buildings are crowded together in the character of a medieval settlement.  All have steeply pitched roofs and chimneystacks that punctuate their rooflines.  Only the upper section of the tower is visible but the visible façade contains two round-arched windows consisting of a double-lancet and trefoil format.  Immediately above this is a blind arcade.  This is separated from the next story above by a projecting cornice.  The tower has four narrow lancet window openings directly below the roofline.  The roofline is broken slightly as it meets the cornice.  A figural finial, possibly a rooster or hen, surmounts the roof.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Three Sketches of Building Details, Antwerp

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating three masonry façades, clockwise from top left:  View from the rear of a "crow's step" or "trap gevel" masonry building façade.  The façade has been reinforced vertically at the center with corbelling.  Directly below this is a square opening from which projects out a square rod, ending in a curved or angled flange.  Marked D (inscribed in circle) and noted as Anthwerp [sic].  Next is a view of the "crow's step" or "trap gevel" masonry façade bearing a date marker plate that reads 1580.  This is possibly the façade of the same building in the previous sketch, but at the opposite end.  The façade has many steps creating a strong, triangular shape.  A single string course separates the upper six steps from those below.  Within this space is a square opening and what appears to be the face of a male figure in stone.  Below the datemarker are three window openings, and possibly the decorative ends of tie rods.  This sketch is noted as: E (inscribed in circle), Back (underlined), Antwerp / Aug 17th 1887.  The final sketch is marked F (inscribed in circle) and noted as: Front (underlined).  It is the view of another 'trapgevel' masonry façade, though much more ornamental with the addition of scroll work elements that end each of the three steps, in a fashion typical of Northern Dutch and Flemish cities.  The top step projects high and is completed with a projecting cornice cap.  Directly below this seems to be a symbol, a cross inscribed within a circle, possibly indicating a religious edifice.  It is possible that sketches E and F are the opposite façades of this building, while sketch D is the back of the façade illustrated in sketch E.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting conical masonry tower pierced at intervals by small rectangular window openings, surmounted by a four-armed wood structure meant to catch the wind.  This structure moves on a central pivot that seems to anchor to the back of the structure.  Below the arms is a walkway that encircles the tower and is visibly supported by timber buttresses from underneath.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Sketch for a Navle [sic] Battle (after) van de Velde, Rotterdam

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet tipped vertically into binding depicting many large warships surrounded and shrouded by clouds of smoke, likely from cannon and gun fire.  In the foreground two ships are well rendered, each carrying an identicaly striped flag.  In the center background of the scene, sails and the flag of another ship emerge from the smoke.  This ship carries a flag similar to that of the United Kingdom of Great Britain, with the cross of St. George laid over the crosses of St. Andrew and St. Patrick.  The ships all have double masts and full, billowing sails with guns drawn.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet bound vertically in album.  Depicted are warships on the ocean, possibly related to 1943-51-96 and 1943-51-94.  The ships are entirely shrouded by smoke or fog.  The scene has a chaotic feel, and it is not possible to discern the ships beyond those in the foreground.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and gray wash, graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet bound vertically in album.  A view of a fleet of warships (man-o-war) which face away from the viewer with the stern of the ships visible.  Only the ship at the far left is visible from the side.  It and the boat closest to it carry the flag of Great Britain.  Many of the ships are concealed from full view by fog or smoke.  See also 1943-51-94; 1943-51-95.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and wash, graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
